title: 113_s1812
content: The "Emergency Port of Entry Personnel and Infrastructure Funding Act of 2013" defines key terms such as Administrator, Commissioner, Northern border, Secretary, and Southern border. It also addresses U.S. Customs and Border Protection personnel. The "Emergency Port of Entry Personnel and Infrastructure Funding Act of 2013" defines key terms and addresses U.S. Customs and Border Protection personnel enhancements, including hiring 5,000 officers and 350 support staff by September 30, 2019. The Secretary can waive fte limitations to assign more personnel for Homeland Security. A report must be submitted within 90 days on plans for outbound inspections at Southern border land ports of entry. The Secretary must submit a report within 90 days outlining plans for sufficient personnel for outbound inspections at Southern border land ports of entry, including U.S. Customs and Border Protection agriculture specialists, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service entomologist identifier specialists, and Food and Drug Administration consumer safety officers. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report detailing the implementation plan for staff enhancements at Southern border land ports of entry, including the number of additional personnel assigned, distribution methodology for cross-border inspections, and other relevant details. The Secretary must submit an annual report outlining the strategic plan, model, and outcome-based performance measures. Additionally, U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers must have secure communication devices for effective communication between ports of entry and with other law enforcement agencies. The Secretary will establish a grant program for purchasing identification and detection equipment, as well as communication devices for State and local law enforcement officers on the Southern border. The Commissioner may assist in enforcing customs, immigration, and agriculture laws by designing and modifying ports of entry infrastructure. The Commissioner is responsible for acquiring land, constructing ports of entry, and prioritizing projects to reduce vehicle and pedestrian traffic at the borders. The Secretary aims to reduce wait times, increase efficiency, and enhance safety at ports of entry on the same border through consultation with various agencies and stakeholders. The Secretary aims to determine new port locations while minimizing adverse impacts on the environment, historic resources, and communities near the ports. This subsection does not create rights or liabilities, affect the legality of the Secretary's determinations, or impact consultation requirements under other laws. The Secretary may acquire leasehold interests and construct or modify facilities to implement the Act. $1 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2014-2019, with $5 million for grants. Unobligated federal funds are rescinded to offset costs. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will determine and identify appropriation accounts for rescission of unobligated funds equal to the authorized amount. A report must be submitted to Congress within 60 days detailing the accounts and amounts identified. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will identify unobligated funds for rescission, with exceptions for the Department of Defense, Veterans Affairs, and Homeland Security. SEC. 4. CROSS-BORDER TRADE ENHANCEMENT. The Administrator may enter agreements or accept donations for port infrastructure. Evaluation procedures must be established within 180 days. The Administrator can enter agreements or accept donations for port infrastructure, including construction, alteration, operation, or maintenance of facilities at land border ports of entry. Donations may specify the facility or facilities they support. The Administrator must return donated property or services if not used for specified facilities or within the designated time frame. Within 90 days of receiving a proposal, the Administrator must determine and notify regarding construction or maintenance at a land border port of entry. The Administrator must make a determination on approving a proposal for construction or maintenance at a land border port of entry within 90 days. Factors considered include the impact on reducing wait times at that port and other ports on the same border. If the proposal is not approved, reasons for disapproval must be provided to the submitter. The Administrator must approve proposals for construction or maintenance at land border ports of entry within 90 days. Factors considered include reducing wait times at ports on the same border, increasing trade and travel efficiency, and enhancing security. Delegated facilities fall under the Secretary's authority. SEC. 5. IMPLEMENTATION OF GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTABILITY OFFICE FINDINGS. Border Wait Time Data Collection strategic plan development includes ensuring standardized manual wait time collection practices, incorporating data into online platforms, and identifying a measurement tool for validation. The Secretary will develop a standardized model for staff allocation at land ports of entry, considering operational priorities, historical staffing levels, and anticipated traffic flows. The Secretary will identify outcome-based performance measures supporting trade facilitation goals of U.S. Customs and Border Protection, including benefits for trusted traveler and shipper program participants like decreased wait times and fewer referrals to secondary inspection. The Secretary will submit a report within 90 days after the enactment of the Act, detailing new performance measures and their incorporation into existing measures.
